notes: Third generation W204 facelift (2011-2014). C63 AMG features naturally aspirated 6.2L V8. Available in sedan and coupe variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz C-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation W205 (2014-2021). C43 AMG features twin-turbo V6, C63 AMG has twin-turbo V8. Available in sedan, coupe, convertible variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz C-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Fourth generation W212 (2009-2016). E63 AMG features 5.5L twin-turbo V8. Available in sedan, coupe, convertible, wagon variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz E-Class article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation W212 facelift (2013-2016). E63 AMG S produces 577 hp. Refreshed styling and updated engines. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz E-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation W213 (2016-present). E63 S AMG produces 603 hp with drift mode. Available in sedan, coupe, convertible, wagon variants. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz E-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Fifth generation W221 facelift (2009-2013). S63 AMG features 5.5L twin-turbo V8, S65 AMG has 6.0L twin-turbo V12. Advanced air suspension requires specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz S-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth generation W222 (2013-2020). S63 AMG features 4.0L twin-turbo V8, S65 AMG has 6.0L twin-turbo V12. Magic Body Control air suspension. Coupe variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz S-Class article, January 2025 revision.

First generation C117 (2013-2019). CLA45 AMG produces 375 hp with 4MATIC AWD. First FWD-based Mercedes sedan in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz CLA-Class article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation C218 (2010-2018). CLS63 AMG S produces 577 hp. Four-door coupe styling. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation C257 (2018-2024). CLS53 AMG features I6 turbo with EQ Boost mild hybrid. Four-door coupe design. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class article, January 2025 revision.
First generation X156 (2013-2020). GLA45 AMG produces 375 hp with 4MATIC. Based on A-Class platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLA-Class article, January 2025 revision.
First generation X253 (2015-2023). Replaces GLK. GLC43/GLC63 AMG variants available. Coupe body style introduced. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLC-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Third generation W166 facelift (2015-2019). Renamed from M-Class to GLE. GLE63 S AMG produces 577 hp. Coupe variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLE-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation X166 facelift (2015-2019). Renamed from GL-Class to GLS. GLS63 AMG produces 577 hp. Seven-passenger seating. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GLS-Class article, January 2025 revision.

First generation W463 (1990-2018). Body-on-frame construction with three locking differentials. G55 AMG features supercharged V8. Requires familiarity with complex 4WD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz G-Class article, January 2025 revision.

First generation W463 facelift (2012-2018). G63 AMG features 5.5L twin-turbo V8. Updated styling but retains classic design. Three locking differentials. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz G-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation R172 facelift (2016-2020). Renamed from SLK to SLC. Retractable hardtop convertible. SLC43 AMG variant available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz SLC-Class article, January 2025 revision.
Sixth generation R231 (2012-2020). Retractable hardtop. SL63 AMG produces up to 577 hp, SL65 AMG has 621 hp V12. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz SL-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Sixth generation R231 facelift (2016-2020). Updated engines and styling. SL63 AMG features 4.0L twin-turbo V8. Retractable hardtop. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz SL-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation W246 (2011-2018). Compact MPV design. FWD transverse platform. Not as popular in North American market. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz B-Class article, January 2025 revision.
Third generation W166 (2011-2015). ML63 AMG features 5.5L twin-turbo V8. Renamed to GLE in 2015 facelift. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz M-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation X166 (2012-2016). GL63 AMG produces 550 hp. Seven-passenger seating. Renamed to GLS in 2016 facelift. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz GL-Class article, January 2025 revision.

Second generation R172 (2011-2016). SLK55 AMG features naturally aspirated 5.5L V8. Retractable hardtop. Renamed to SLC in 2016. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mercedes-Benz SLK-Class article, January 2025 revision.
